newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia agency delays crude palm oil exports.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia agency delays crude palm oil exports.

text.p: Indonesia's state-run Joint Marketing Board (KPB) has delayed export shipments of about 20,000 tonnes of crude palm oil due to a drop in production, a KPB official told Reuters on Tuesday.
"The shipments have been delayed to June from May because of a drop in production," the official said, adding that the volume was about 30 to 50 percent of its total monthly exports.
The official said he had no details on the production shortfall, but added that the agency's crude palm oil allocation to local refiners was not affected.
State plantations, which account for about 40 percent of total national production, export 30 percent of their output through the KPB and channel the rest to the domestic market.

Traders said production in Indonesia, the world's top palm oil producer after neighbouring Malaysia, had declined steadily from late last year because of weather-related problems, and an insufficient supply of fertilisers to state-run plantations.
The Indonesian Palm Oil Producers Association had forecast 1996 output at 4.9 million tonnes, up from 4.5 million in 1995.
